contentTypes.name: Hero Section
contentTypes.description: Top banner with headline, subheadline, background image

contentTypes.name: Home page
contentTypes.description: Main page that defines the title, slug, metadata, sections and etc... Sections are ordered to build the page layout.

contentTypes.name: Footer
contentTypes.description: Footer content

contentTypes.name: MetaAndShare
contentTypes.description: Metadata and Share content at the page level

contentTypes.name: Section
contentTypes.description: Represents a section block on a page

contentTypes.name: Image Tile Widget
contentTypes.description: Widget that displays an image with a title, description, and link. Successive uses of this widget start with the image on the left for the first widget and then alternate layout orientations.

contentTypes.name: Text Widget
contentTypes.description: Widget that creates a text block

contentTypes.name: Accordion Widget
contentTypes.description: Accordion widget to organize content into collapsible sections.

contentTypes.name: Modules Page
contentTypes.description: Container Page for multiple wellness modules with tabbed navigation.

contentTypes.name: Button
contentTypes.description: Button with text, link and link behavior

contentTypes.name: Card
contentTypes.description: Part of layout that includes icon, title, body text, action button etc...

contentTypes.name: Module
contentTypes.description: Content displayed for each module

contentTypes.name: Day Program
contentTypes.description: includes content per day

contentTypes.name: Week Planner Navigation
contentTypes.description: tabbed day navigation

contentTypes.name: Video Card
contentTypes.description: Individual video card

contentTypes.name: Video Category Tab
contentTypes.description: Category tab for filtering videos

contentTypes.name: Video Carousel Block
contentTypes.description: Video carousel block with filtering tabs

contentTypes.name: Icon
contentTypes.description: Includes Icon and Alt Text

contentTypes.name: Microstep Card
contentTypes.description: Each card contains a label, short title and description to encourage simple, healthy habits.

contentTypes.name: Microsteps Block
contentTypes.description: Block Contains label, cards and the button

contentTypes.name: Image Cover Block
contentTypes.description: Includes label, heading and  image as a background

contentTypes.name: Benefits Block
contentTypes.description: Includes label, title, body text and button

contentTypes.name: Article
contentTypes.description: Each entry includes a title, label, image, and descriptive body text, along with optional tags for categorization or filtering.

contentTypes.name: Articles Block
contentTypes.description: Use this model to display a list of articles on Modules Page. It defines the overall block structure  including a top section with heading and button, a middle section listing articles (referencing shared Article entries), and bottom call-to-action button.

contentTypes.name: Option
contentTypes.description: Includes icon, title and description

contentTypes.name: Save Later Block
contentTypes.description: Includes a call-to-action and a list of options, each with an icon, title, and description.

entryName.en-US: Consumer Health Privacy Notice Navigation Link

description.en-US:
This brief guide will introduce you to the Lilly Health and Well-being Program, a five-week, self-paced program to help participants build healthy habits that last. The program is built around three key ideas: - Focus on 5 behaviors: Five core behaviors nutrition, movement, sleep, stress management, and connection form the foundation of sustainable health.

- Shift Your Mindset: By reframing healthy living as something rewarding and fun rather than restrictive, participants may be more likely to stick with it.

- Start Small with Microsteps: Microsteps are tiny, practical actions that l ower the barrier to change

altText.en-US: A man with a kid sitting on his shoulders

key.en-US: Health and Well-being Program Widget  Description

text.en-US:
Participants will have access to an introductory guide and five self-paced modules, each focused on a core health behavior  nutrition, movement, sleep, stress management, and connection.

While participants can proceed at their own pace, each module is designed as a week-long experience. Each module includes:
- 3 Microsteps per day
- Short daily lessons explaining the concepts
- Scientific reference

description.en-US:
Small, consistent actions, known as Microsteps, are the building blocks of the Lilly Health and Well-being program. Microsteps help: - __Make big goals achievable__: Microsteps break down large, often overwhelming goals into small, manageable actions, making it easier to take the first step and build momentum.

- __Reduce resistance to change__: Because Microsteps are too small to fail, they lower psychological resistance, helping people overcome procrastination and fear of failure.

- __Support long-term habits__: By being easy to repeat consistently, Microsteps help embed new behaviors into daily routines, making it easier to create lasting, sustainable habits

title.en-US: The Lilly Health and Well-being Program

key.en-US: Health and Well-being Program Widget  Description

text.en-US:
Participants will have access to an introductory guide and five self-paced modules, each focused on a core health behavior nutrition, movement, sleep, stress management, and connection. While participants can proceed at their own pace, each module is designed as a week-long experience. Each module includes: - 3 Microsteps per day

- Short daily lessons explaining the concepts

- Scientific reference

description.en-US:
Healthy eating is one of the most powerful ways to improve energy, focus, mood, and overall well-being  but many people feel confused or overwhelmed about where to start. This 7-day nutrition program takes a simple, inclusive, and sustainable approach, focusing on small, positive steps on which participants can build.

1.  Add more healthy whole foods to your plate
2.  Shop smarter when buying processed foods
3.  Enjoy protein at every meal
4.  Boost your fiber intake with fruits, vegetables, and whole grains
5.  Choose healthy fats like nuts, seeds, and olive oil
6.  Prepare meals and snacks ahead of time to make healthy eating easier
7.  Stay hydrated with water, and limit sugary and artificially-flavored drinks

As a member of the site staff, youre can be a motivator, a guide, and a source of encouragement. Your support for the Lilly Health and Well-being Program helps participants stay engaged, feel seen, and build confidence as they try new habits.

- **Model the message**: Try Microsteps yourself to lead by example and build authentic connection.  
- **Encourage progress, not perfection**: Celebrate small wins and remind participants that every step counts.  
- **Create a welcoming space**: Your positive tone helps participants feel safe, supported, and inspired to keep going.

altText.en-US: Smiling couple preparing a fresh salad in the kitchen.

text.en-US:
### Where to find it Site staff and participants will have easy access to the program through multiple formats. **
RESOURCES:
** - **Printed (paper) version** ordered directly through Hibbert - **Digital version** (to be available in the future): a. Postcard with QR code link b. Email link to the program content c. Program website

### Support Materials This training overview is supported by two key resources for site staff and participants that are available in print format (downloadable version coming soon). **
RESOURCES:
** - **Site staff training guide**: An overview of the Lilly Health and Well-being program - **Participant guide**: The complete Lilly Health and Well-being program consisting of a Welcome module and five core behavior modules.

### Digital Access The digital access portion is under development and currently not available. **
DISTRIBUTION:
** - In the future, both the QR code and email link will direct patients to a digital site. The digital access portion is under development and currently not available. - A communication will be sent out to inform all sites once the digital access features are available.

text.en-US: The program is centered around five behaviors that are deeply interconnected. Improvements in any one area may have a positive ripple effect across the others.

description.en-US:
Movement supports more than just fitness  it improves sleep, strengthens memory, and supports overall well-being. But building a regular movement habit sometimes can feel overwhelming. This 7-day program helps participants take simple, doable steps to build movement into their daily
routines  no matter their age, ability, or fitness level. 

1. Connect your movement goals to your why
2. Habit stack by adding movement to things you already do
3. Break up long periods of sitting
4. Take care of your muscles
5. Move to support cardiac health
6. Support flexibility and mobility
7. Make movement a shared experience

Sleep is essential for physical health, emotional balance, mental clarity, and overall well-being  yet many people overlook it or struggle to get enough. This 7-day program helps participants explore simple Microsteps to build better sleep habits. Each day highlights a different principle of healthy sleep and offers small, manageable ways to make rest a daily priority.

1. Make sleep a daily priority 
2. Go to bed and wake up at the same time each day 
3. Eat well to sleep well (and vice versa) 
4. Create a calm space for sleep 
5. Manage your stress to help your body rest 
6. Move your body during the day to sleep better at night 
7. Build connection to others and to yourself to support restful sleep

Stress touches nearly every part of our lives  from how we think and feel to how we eat, sleep, move, and connect with others. This 7-day program helps participants better understand their personal stress response and introduces practical, science-backed strategies to help manage stress in real time. Each day focuses on a different skill, supported by small, easy-to-try Microsteps. 

1. Identify and respond to your stress triggers 
2. Use your breath to release stress 
3. Build in microbreaks to recharge throughout your day 
4. Move your body to manage stress 
5. Create purposeful downtime and active rest 
6. Focus on one task at a time to reduce stress 
7. Set boundaries with technology

Strong relationships are essential to well-being  they help us manage stress, improve sleep, boost resilience, and bring more joy into everyday life. This 7-day program offers small,
science-backed Microsteps to help participants deepen connections with others and with themselves. 

1. Make connection a daily habit 
2. Pair connection with other healthy habits 
3. Treat yourself like you would treat a friend 
4. Set boundaries with technology when you spend time with others 
5. Connect with someone you don't usually talk to 
6. Do one generous act today 
7. Start a gratitude practice and share it

altText.en-US: Two women hugging closely, conveying warmth and care.

bodyText.en-US: The program begins with a brief introductory guide explaining the structure and the concepts behind the experience.

heading.en-US: Shop smarter when buying processed foods

bodyText.en-US: Eating healthy food is one of the best things you can do for your body and mind. But we know that nutritional advice can sometimes feel confusing or too hard to stick with. Thats why weve created this simple 7-day guide to eating well. Each day includes three Microsteps, which are small actions that make healthy eating easier. You can try just one, or all three. Over time, these little changes may lead to big results.

entryName.en-US: Innovative CONTENT to improve your life

bodyText.en-US:
Moving your body is important for your health 
not just your muscles and heart, but your mind,
memory and emotions too. Being active may help
you think more clearly, feel less stressed, and
sleep better. Even with all these benefits, many
people find it challenging to be active every day.

Moving your body is important for your health 
not just your muscles and heart, but your mind,
memory and emotions too. Being active may help
you think more clearly, feel less stressed, and
sleep better. Even with all these benefits, many
people find it challenging to be active every day.

heading.en-US: Break up long periods of sitting

title.en-US: Fill half your plate with colorful vegetables or fruits.

bodyText.en-US: Adding more fruits and vegetables helps to naturally crowd out less nutritious foods. Try adding something orange, green, red, or purple using foods available in your local market or grocery store. Eating a variety of colors supports better nutrition.

title.en-US: Shop for a whole grain you havent cooked with before.

bodyText.en-US: Try brown rice, oats, millet, maize, farro, or bulgur. Whole grains are a great source of lasting energy and essential nutrients.

title.en-US: Try a new healthy cooking method like steaming, roasting, or stir-frying with minimal oil.

bodyText.en-US: These methods help keep the nutrients in your food while reducing extra fats.

title.en-US: Read food labels and choose processed foods made with ingredients youd find in your own kitchen.

bodyText.en-US: Processed foods made with ingredients you might cook with at home tend to be more nutritious and less processed than those with long, chemical-sounding ingredient lists.

title.en-US: Instead of crisps (also known as potato chips) or packaged sweets, try switching to a whole food option like fruit or nuts one time this week.

bodyText.en-US: This small change can reduce added sugar and salt while increasing nutrients and healthy fats.

title.en-US: Count the number of ingredients on one processed food you normally buy.

bodyText.en-US: If it contains more than two or three unfamiliar ingredients, try switching to a brand with a shorter, simpler ingredient list.

heading.en-US: Add healthy whole foods to your plate

bodyText.en-US:
Eating healthy doesnt mean giving up all your favorite foods. A great way to get started is to focus on what you can add to your plate, not what you have to take away.  

One simple tip is to eat the rainbow. This means trying to eat fruits and vegetables in many colors  like orange, green, red, purple, white, and yellow. Each color gives your body different nutrients to help you stay strong and feel your best.  

For example:  
- Orange foods like carrots or pumpkin contain beta-carotene, a nutrient that helps support good vision.  
- Green leafy vegetables are high in calcium and vitamin K, which is important for strong bones.  
- Red and purple foods are packed with compounds that protect your cells from damage.  
- Yellow foods like bananas, yellow squash, corn, and yellow peppers contain vitamin C, vitamin A, and other compounds that help keep your skin healthy and protect your body from illness.  

Wherever you live, try to eat a colorful mix of foods that are local, fresh, or in season. Or just add chopped greens, beans, or lentils to a dish you already make.  

If your meals include some processed foods, thats OK too  just try adding something fresh, like a vegetable or fruit, to go along with it.  

When you add more whole foods to your meals  like fruits, vegetables, beans, lentils, whole grains, and nuts  you are more likely to feel full and have steady energy throughout the day.  

It also helps to cook in ways that keep your food healthy and tasty  like steaming, boiling, roasting, or stir-frying with a small amount of oil.  

You dont have to be a food expert or master chef to eat well. Start with what you already like to eat and build from there.

entryName.en-US: Innovative CONTENT to improve your life

heading.en-US: Connect your movement goals to your why

bodyText.en-US:
Moving your body is important for your health  not just your muscles and heart, but your mind,
memory and emotions too. Being active may help you think more clearly, feel less stressed, and
sleep better. Even with all these benefits, many people find it challenging to be active every day.

But heres some good news: you dont have to do it all at once. Small bits of movement throughout
the day  whether its taking regular walk breaks or stretching during television commercials
 can still make a difference. This seven-day guide will get you started with daily movement
Microsteps  small, science-backed actions you can try right away. So, lets get moving, one Microstep at a time!

Good sleep helps your brain, body and mood stay healthy. It gives you the energy to focus during
the day and take care of yourself and the people around you.

For many of us, sleep gets pushed aside when life gets busy. This simple 7-day sleep program is
here to help you make small, easy changes that can help you rest better  one day at a time.

Each day includes Microsteps  small actions you can try right away. These small changes can
help your body and brain reset, so you feel more rested and ready to face the day.

body.en-US:
Medicare Part D, the program that provides prescription drug coverage for our nations seniors, is being updated to make medicines more affordable and accessible for beneficiaries. Patients, caregivers and health care providers should be aware of three key changes that will go into effect in 2025:

---

### 1. **$2,000 out-of-pocket maximum and elimination of coverage gap phase**

In 2025, Part D enrollees will pay no more than $2,000 for medications.  
The coverage gap phase (aka donut hole) will be eliminated.

![2025 Medicare Benefit Redesign](https://images.ctfassets.net/pixe68huo2dd/3QuFqH35Hu6b3pLVVAWMUz/ea96f9c0d646e167c7938ab91d75f708/Medicare_D_Benefit_Design_Chart___1.png)

---

### 2. **New monthly prescription payment plan**

In 2025, enrollees can opt-in to a new payment structure that lets them pay for medications in equal monthly amounts over the year, rather than large sums upfront at the pharmacy counter.  
This option can help with affordability, especially for those on fixed incomes.

---

### 3. **Expanded eligibility for the Low-Income Subsidy (LIS) program**

- The LIS program helps eligible people with limited incomes pay for their drug plans premiums, deductibles, and copayments.
- Starting in 2025, more people will qualify, including individuals up to **150% of the Federal Poverty Level (FPL)**.

|                         | Standard Benefit | Partial Subsidy | Full Subsidy |
|-------------------------|------------------|------------------|--------------|
| **Deductible**          | $545             | $104             | $0           |
| **Initial Coverage**    | 25% coinsurance  | 15% coinsurance  | $1.55 / $4.60|
| **Catastrophic Phase**  | 0% coinsurance   | 15% coinsurance  | $0           |

---

###  **BONUS TIP: Know your right to appeal.**

If a prescription is denied or not covered, patients can:
- Request a coverage determination
- File an appeal if denied
- Request an expedited decision in urgent cases

Learn more about your appeal rights at: [medicare.gov](https://www.medicare.gov)

heading.en-US: Move your body during the day to sleep better at night

bodyText.en-US:
Good sleep helps your brain, body and mood stay healthy. It gives you the energy to focus during
the day and take care of yourself and the people around you.

For many of us, sleep gets pushed aside when life gets busy. This simple 7-day sleep program is
here to help you make small, easy changes that can help you rest better  one day at a time.

Each day includes Microsteps  small actions you can try right away. These small changes can
help your body and brain reset, so you feel more rested and ready to face the day.

heading.en-US: Build connection  to others and to yourself  to support restful sleep

key.en-US: FAQ - How do enrollees apply for LIS (Extra Help)?

title.en-US: How do enrollees apply for LIS (Extra Help)?

key.en-US: How do enrollees apply for LIS (Extra Help)?

text.en-US:
According to the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services, up to 3 million people are 
eligible for Extra Help, also called LIS, but have not enrolled.8Eligibility can be 
determined by applying online athttps://www.ssa.gov/medicare/part-d-extra-helpor by 
calling the Social Security Administration at1-800-772-1213.

key.en-US: Is there an open enrollment period to apply for LIS (Extra Help)?

text.en-US:
No, there is no open enrollment period to apply for Extra Help. You can apply anytime 
throughout the year without any late enrollment penalties.9

key.en-US: What is the Part D enrollee annual out-of-pocket maximum for covered medications in 2024 and in 2025?

text.en-US: The annual out-of-pocket maximum is $3,300 in 2024 and $2,000 in 2025.1

heading.en-US: Use your breath to release stress

bodyText.en-US:
We all feel stress  its a normal part of life. But when we feel stressed all the time, it can wear us down. It can make us feel tired, moody, or tense. It can even affect how well we sleep, eat, and move our bodies. 

Stress can show up in many ways. Maybe your heart beats faster. Maybe your muscles feel tight. Maybe you feel anxious or overwhelmed. This is your bodys way of getting ready to deal with a problem. That can be helpful for a short time  but living in a stressed out mode all day, every day, may impact your health. 

The good news? You can learn small ways to help calm your body and your mind. Each day of this 7-day program includes three Microsteps  small actions that make managing stress easier. You can do just one or all of them, whatever feels right for you. 

Whether youre working in an office or factory, caregiving, running a household, retired or a student studying for school, learning how to manage and release stress is an important skill.

Lets get started  one breath and one Microstep at a time.

Strong relationships help us feel happy. Whether its a good friend, a kind coworker, someone who takes care of us, or even a friendly moment with a stranger, connection makes us feel seen and supported.

Connection also helps with other parts of our health. It may potentially lower stress, help us sleep better, and it may make us more likely to take care of ourselves and others. For the next seven days, this guide will share seven simple strategies to help you build stronger connections. Every day this week, youll find three Microsteps  small, practical actions that you can take to help make connection a daily priority.

body.en-US:
Site staff and participants will have easy access to the program through multiple formats. **
RESOURCES:
** - **Printed (paper) version** ordered directly through Hibbert - **Digital version** (to be available in the future): a. Postcard with QR code link b. Email link to the program content c. Program website

This training overview is supported by two key resources for site staff and participants that are available in print format (downloadable version coming soon). **
RESOURCES:
** - **Site staff training guide**: An overview of the Lilly Health and Well-being program - **Participant guide**: The complete Lilly Health and Well-being program consisting of a Welcome module and five core behavior modules.

The digital access portion is under development and currently not available. **
DISTRIBUTION:
** - In the future, both the QR code and email link will direct patients to a digital site. The digital access portion is under development and currently not available. - A communication will be sent out to inform all sites once the digital access features are available.

description.en-US:
Healthy eating is one of the most powerful ways to improve energy, focus, mood, and overall well-being  but many people feel confused or overwhelmed about where to start. This 7-day nutrition program takes a simple, inclusive, and sustainable approach, focusing on small, positive steps on which participants can build.

1.  Add more healthy whole foods to your plate
2.  Shop smarter when buying processed foods
3.  Enjoy protein at every meal
4.  Boost your fiber intake with fruits, vegetables, and whole grains
5.  Choose healthy fats like nuts, seeds, and olive oil
6.  Prepare meals and snacks ahead of time to make healthy eating easier
7.  Stay hydrated with water, and limit sugary and artificially-flavored drinks

Movement supports more than just fitness  it improves sleep, strengthens memory, and supports overall well-being. But building a regular movement habit sometimes can feel overwhelming. This 7-day program helps participants take simple, doable steps to build movement into their daily
routines  no matter their age, ability, or fitness level. 

1. Connect your movement goals to your why
2. Habit stack by adding movement to things you already do
3. Break up long periods of sitting
4. Take care of your muscles
5. Move to support cardiac health
6. Support flexibility and mobility
7. Make movement a shared experience

Sleep is essential for physical health, emotional balance, mental clarity, and overall well-being  yet many people overlook it or struggle to get enough. This 7-day program helps participants explore simple Microsteps to build better sleep habits. Each day highlights a different principle of healthy sleep and offers small, manageable ways to make rest a daily priority.

1. Make sleep a daily priority 
2. Go to bed and wake up at the same time each day 
3. Eat well to sleep well (and vice versa) 
4. Create a calm space for sleep 
5. Manage your stress to help your body rest 
6. Move your body during the day to sleep better at night 
7. Build connection to others and to yourself to support restful sleep

Stress touches nearly every part of our lives  from how we think and feel to how we eat, sleep, move, and connect with others. This 7-day program helps participants better understand their personal stress response and introduces practical, science-backed strategies to help manage stress in real time. Each day focuses on a different skill, supported by small, easy-to-try Microsteps. 

1. Identify and respond to your stress triggers 
2. Use your breath to release stress 
3. Build in microbreaks to recharge throughout your day 
4. Move your body to manage stress 
5. Create purposeful downtime and active rest 
6. Focus on one task at a time to reduce stress 
7. Set boundaries with technology

Strong relationships are essential to well-being  they help us manage stress, improve sleep, boost resilience, and bring more joy into everyday life. This 7-day program offers small,
science-backed Microsteps to help participants deepen connections with others and with themselves. 

1. Make connection a daily habit 
2. Pair connection with other healthy habits 
3. Treat yourself like you would treat a friend 
4. Set boundaries with technology when you spend time with others 
5. Connect with someone you don't usually talk to 
6. Do one generous act today 
7. Start a gratitude practice and share it
